Problem Overview

This Problem focuses on how unit rate, or constant of proportionality, is helpful to solve problems. Students also look at the role of unit rate in different representations of tables, graphs, and equations. Students began their study of multiplicative relationships in the 6th grade unit, Factoring Structure.

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Introduce the term constant of proportionality and connect it to unit rate.

Use unit rates to solve problems.

Begin to identify and use the constant of proportionality in tables, graphs, and equations and understand how it makes it easy to compare different rates and solve problems.

NWDYK

Describe how you can determine a unit rate, or constant of proportionality, in a description, rate table, equation, or graph?

In what ways is a unit rate or the constant of proportionality helpful for solving a problem?

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

If you did not introduce the vocabulary of constant of proportionality in the Summary of Problem 2.2, you can introduce the term now. Since the quantities for Royal Pizza are proportional, the constant of proportionality is 13. Since the quantities for Howdy’s Pizza are not proportional, there is no constant of proportionality.

If we let C represent the cost of a pizza and N represent the number of pizzas,

Royal Pizza

With the proportional situation, both equations are equivalent. You can multiply one variable by a constant number to get the value of the other variable.

Howdy’s Pizza

Linear Equation: C = 11N + 30

You cannot write C = 11N + 30 as a proportion. The add-on changes the unit rate with each N. So there is no constant of proportionality. You cannot multiply one variable by a constant number to get the value of the other variable.
Note: The unit rate, 5/65 pizza for $1, exists but it might not be as useful depending on the situation.

Presenting the Challenge

Students will be analyzing the proportionality in descriptions, tables, graphs, and equations. Let students know that the situation involves a sale on oranges where they are 10 oranges for $2. Students will analyze how they can use this information to think about buying any number of oranges. Have students begin this work independently for a few minutes and then work with a partner.
